p: Messaoud et al. [ 37] report of some Gas Chromatography-Mass Spectrometry (GC-MS) analyses of essential oils extracts from mature dark blue and white berries of Tunisian Myrtus communis samples growing at the same site, which allowed the identification of 33 chemical components. The oils from dark blue fruits showed high percentages of α-pinene (11.1%), linalool (11.6%), α-terpineol (15.7%), methyl eugenol (6.2%), and geraniol (3.7%). Myrtenyl acetate (20.3%) was found to be the major compound in the oils from white berries.
